Rohingya refugees in Cox's Bazar endure inhumane living conditions, with no investment in their living conditions or education, leading to a dire situation as conditions in the camps continue to deteriorate[11][14]. These refugees are particularly vulnerable to extreme weather events such as cyclones and landslides, and climate-induced hazards like floods and cyclones pose additional threats, resulting in internal displacement[11][16]. The camps have also experienced fires, including incidents where LPG gas canisters exploded, causing significant damage[12][14]. Health challenges are rampant, with outbreaks of diseases such as diphtheria, cholera, measles, COVID-19, scabies, and dengue, exacerbated by waste around the camps[12][18].

In response to Cyclone Remal, World Vision Bangladesh (WVB) has scaled up its efforts to support vulnerable children and communities. The organization is on high alert, prioritizing safety and providing critical support for coastal communities, children, and families[21]. Local mobilization is key to their cyclone preparedness and anticipatory action, with the World Vision BRCR team mobilizing a rapid response to aid fire survivors and prepare for the storm's impact[21][25][28]. Essential relief materials, including dry food supplies, have been prepositioned throughout the region, and trained staff with logistical equipment are ready for rapid deployment[23]. Emergency Operation Centers have been activated to facilitate a swift response, and coordination with other NGOs, UN agencies, and government bodies ensures a comprehensive approach that prioritizes the needs of affected children and communities[23][27][28]. Additionally, World Vision's Child Protection Team has provided foster care services and reunified missing children with their families[24].

The Needs Assessment Working Group (NAWG), a platform for government and non-government humanitarian agencies under the Humanitarian Coordination Task Team (HCTT), has conducted an impact analysis of Cyclone Remal[31][33][34]. NAWG compiles and interpolates information from sources like the India Meteorological Department (IMD) and Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) for its reports, which are intended for internal use by NAWG Bangladesh Members for preparatory activities[35][38]. Their analysis indicates that up to 1.9 million people are at risk, with an exposed population of 11 million in areas experiencing wind speeds of 110-120 km/h[31][33][41].

UNICEF has established three contingency partnerships with civil society organizations (CSOs) ready for activation in cyclone-affected areas, with an additional 19 partnerships available for reprogramming in emergencies[71][72]. The World Food Programme (WFP) has provided 3,400 Rohingya refugees with fortified biscuits as part of their response to Cyclone Remal, and ongoing needs assessments are being conducted to evaluate the potential damage[172][173].

The global humanitarian funding crisis, characterized by a significant shortfall, has hindered the ability of organizations to meet their targets, assisting less than two-thirds of the people they aimed to support in 2023[111][114]. This crisis is exacerbated by conflicts, climate emergencies, and collapsing economies, leading to catastrophic hunger, massive displacement, and disease outbreaks[112]. The need for more flexible funding mechanisms, such as multi-year funding and reduced restrictions on fund allocation, is crucial to enhance the effectiveness of support[115].

To reduce the vulnerability of low-income households to cyclones and other climate-related disasters, several measures can be implemented. These include poverty reduction, infrastructure and housing improvements, access to basic resources, early warning systems, agricultural productivity, financial resilience, strong governance and support, and human capital development[151][152][154][156][157][158][159][160].

The World Food Programme (WFP) has developed an Anticipatory Action (AA) programme designed to prevent and mitigate the effects of extreme weather on the food security and nutrition of highly vulnerable populations[41][42]. This initiative allows for the implementation and financing of proactive measures before an extreme weather event occurs[41][42]. A key component of this programme is the provision of forecast-based cash assistance, which helps families prepare for and recover from impending storms[46][48]. This assistance enables families to purchase essential items such as food, medicines, and cattle feed[45][48], and to take protective measures like reinforcing their homes with ropes or arranging transportation to safer locations[45]. The cash distribution is supported by early warning messages and evacuation assistance, coordinated with local government authorities[46].

In Bangladesh, WFP collaborates with national and local government partners to develop early-warning systems and anticipatory actions for critical natural hazards, including floods, cyclones, flash floods, and heavy rainfall[42]. As part of these initiatives, WFP finalizes beneficiary databases for flood-prone areas in the northeast and cyclone-prone areas in the southwestern regions[43]. To ensure efficiency and avoid duplication, WFP works closely with partners to verify beneficiary databases[49]. Additionally, WFP participates in Disaster Management Committee (DMC) meetings to ensure a coordinated approach to preparedness and response[49]. Its cooperating partners assist Cyclone Shelter Management Committees (SMCs)[49], and WFP camp retailer partners maintain emergency stocks of food for rapid response[49]. Efforts are also made to mitigate disruptions in transport and telecommunications[49].

In response to Cyclone Remal, which poses a significant threat to nearly 1 million Rohingya people in the world's largest refugee camp, WFP provided 3,400 Rohingya refugees with fortified biscuits[62][63]. Ongoing needs assessments are being conducted to update and determine the extent of potential damage caused by the cyclone[62].

Rohingya refugees in Cox's Bazar endure inhumane living conditions, with no investment in their living conditions or education, leading to a dire situation as conditions in the camps continue to deteriorate[11][14]. These refugees are particularly vulnerable to extreme weather events like cyclones and landslides, and climate-induced hazards such as floods and cyclones pose additional threats, leading to internal displacement[11][16]. Fires have also occurred in the camps, including an incident where an LPG gas canister exploded in a hut, setting it on fire[12][14]. Health challenges are rampant, with outbreaks of diseases such as diphtheria, cholera, measles, COVID-19, scabies, and dengue[12]. Skin diseases like dengue, eczema, and scabies are spreading rapidly due to waste around the camps[18].

In Khulna, residents, particularly around the Notun Bazar area, regularly use saline water for cooking, drinking, and bathing[21]. The increasing salinisation of freshwater resources in the region is putting the health of local populations under greater threat, becoming a major health hazard with deadly consequences[23][24]. Research has investigated the effects of water salinity on kidney health, finding that drinking-water sodium and urinary sodium are associated with increased protein excretion, a powerful marker for kidney disease[22][30]. Among 1,185 trial participants, 37 had mild proteinuria and 20 had moderate or substantial proteinuria[32]. Chronic kidney disease (CKD) has been diagnosed in Khulna, with one individual's kidneys not working properly for nearly seven years, severely affecting her heart, lungs, and central nervous system[24][28][36]. An increase in kidney-related diseases is expected if water quality does not improve[25][38].

Extreme heat in Khulna has led to a rise in hospital admissions, with patients occupying corridors and stairways as wards ran out of beds[31]. High temperatures cause profound sweating, loss of body fluid, and dehydration, affecting both men and women in tropical regions[31][34]. The water crisis, including a lack of suitable drinking water for rehydration, exacerbates these health issues[31][41][43].

In response to Cyclone Remal, several measures have been implemented in Khulna, Bangladesh, to address public health challenges and the healthcare system's capacity. Emergency medical teams have been formed, with 359 teams specifically established in the coastal districts of Bagerhat, Khulna, and Satkhira[58][60][81]. Civil Surgeons have been instructed to ensure adequate medicines and logistics are prepositioned in hospitals, including water purification tablets (WPT), IV saline, oral rehydration solution (ORS), and first aid kits with anti-snake venoms[60][91][101]. Additionally, 706 Government Primary Schools (GPSs) have been identified and converted into cyclone shelters to accommodate families at risk[60][101].

World Vision Bangladesh (WVB) is actively supporting vulnerable children and communities affected by Cyclone Remal by scaling up response efforts and prioritizing safety and critical support for coastal communities[111]. WVB has prepositioned essential relief materials, including dry food supplies, and trained staff and logistical equipment are strategically positioned for rapid deployment[113]. The organization is coordinating with other NGOs, UN agencies, and government bodies to ensure a comprehensive response that prioritizes the needs of affected children and communities[117][118].

The Needs Assessment Working Group (NAWG) has conducted an impact analysis of Cyclone Remal, projecting that up to 1.9 million people are at risk, with an exposed population of 11 million in areas with high wind speeds[121][131]. NAWG functions as a platform for government and non-government humanitarian agencies under the Humanitarian Coordination Task Team (HCTT), compiling information from sources like the India Meteorological Department (IMD) and Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) for its reports[123][124][128].

Current gaps in early warning systems have significant implications for cyclone preparedness in regions like Bangladesh, where accurate forecasts and useful early warnings are hindered by unavailable weather data from exclusive economic zones[171]. These gaps prevent timely evacuations, increasing vulnerability in lower-income countries[173][178]. To address the impact of Cyclone Remal, the World Food Programme (WFP) provided 3,400 Rohingya refugees with fortified biscuits, and ongoing needs assessments are being conducted to determine the extent of potential damage[182][183].

sdg-11.summary:
The Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) has been proactive in its response to Cyclone Remal, which is expected to intensify from a depression in the Bay of Bengal into a severe cyclone. The cyclone is projected to make landfall between Kolkata, India, and Patuakhali, Bangladesh, from midnight on May 26 to the early morning of May 27, 2024[21][22]. In anticipation, the BMD issued Danger Signal 10 for several coastal districts, including Khulna, Satkhira, Bagerhat, Pirojpur, Jhalokathi, Barguna, Barishal, Bhola, and Patuakhali, as well as their offshore islands and chars[21][22]. Azizur Rahman, Director of the BMD, reported that Cyclone Remal had begun crossing the Bangladesh coast, with maximum wind speeds recorded at 90 kilometers per hour, potentially increasing further[25][27].

The cyclone is expected to bring maximum wind speeds of 100-110 km/h, with some forecasts predicting winds of 110-120 km/h and gusts up to 135 km/h[21][22][23]. Heavy rainfall is anticipated, posing risks of floods, flash floods, and landslides[21][22]. The storm surge could reach up to 12 feet (four meters) above normal astronomical tide, threatening the low-lying coastal areas[25][28][30]. These areas, including Satkhira, Khulna, Bagerhat, Pirojpur, Jhalokathi, Barguna, Bhola, Patuakhali, Barishal, Noakhali, Lakshmipur, Feni, Cumilla, Chattogram, and Cox's Bazar, face a critical threat of inundation from a wind-driven surge of 3-5 feet above normal tide[21][22][30].

Local mobilization is crucial for cyclone preparedness, with World Vision Bangladesh (WVB) playing a significant role. Over 1,400 community-based groups and nearly 3,000 WVB volunteers are actively involved in disseminating early warning messages and preparing communities[31][34][39][51]. Additionally, 10,000 youth and child forum members are being informed and prepared to take action[39][51]. Awareness campaigns are ongoing to equip families with the knowledge to protect themselves and their belongings[39][51].

The Needs Assessment Working Group (NAWG) has conducted an impact analysis, highlighting that up to 1.9 million people are at risk, with an exposed population of 11 million in areas expecting wind speeds of 110-120 km/h[41]. NAWG, under the Humanitarian Coordination Task Team (HCTT), compiles information from sources like the India Meteorological Department (IMD) and BMD for preparatory activities[41][43][44][45][48].

UNICEF has contingency partnerships with civil society organizations ready for rapid response in cyclone-affected areas, with 19 partnerships available for reprogramming if necessary[71][72]. Coordination with the Cyclone Preparedness Programme (CPP) and local government is essential for evacuating at-risk communities[101].

Current gaps in early warning systems pose challenges for cyclone preparedness in Bangladesh, a country with limited resources[124]. Accurate forecasts require comprehensive data from all regional countries, but a significant data gap exists due to unavailable weather data from exclusive economic zones[121]. This lack of data hinders timely evacuations, increasing vulnerability in lower-income countries[121][123][128].

To mitigate the impact of Cyclone Remal, the World Food Programme (WFP) has provided fortified biscuits to 3,400 Rohingya refugees in the world's largest refugee camp, where nearly 1 million people are at risk[132][133]. Ongoing needs assessments aim to update and determine the potential damage caused by the cyclone[132].

The region's susceptibility to these hazards is compounded by the broader challenges faced by Bangladesh, including the health implications of water salinity and extreme heat in areas like Khulna. sdg-10.summary:
Rohingya refugees in Cox's Bazar endure inhumane living conditions, with no investment in their living conditions or education, leading to a dire situation as conditions in the camps continue to deteriorate[1][4]. These refugees are particularly vulnerable to extreme weather events such as cyclones and landslides, and climate-induced hazards like floods and cyclones further threaten their safety, often resulting in internal displacement[1][6]. The camps have also experienced fires, including incidents where LPG gas canisters exploded, setting huts ablaze[2][4].

Health challenges are rampant, with numerous outbreaks of diseases such as diphtheria, cholera, measles, COVID-19, scabies, and dengue[2]. Skin diseases like dengue, eczema, and scabies are spreading rapidly due to waste accumulation around the camps[8]. This health crisis is compounded by a global humanitarian funding shortfall, which has created a "crisis within a crisis"[11][14]. In 2023, humanitarian organizations were unable to meet their targets, assisting less than two-thirds of the people they aimed to support[11]. Plans for 2024 are ultra-prioritized with extremely tightened budgets[11].

The challenges faced include a widening gap between needs and response, exacerbated by conflicts, climate emergencies, and collapsing economies, leading to catastrophic hunger, massive displacement, and disease outbreaks[12]. The inability to deliver life-saving aid and essential services due to inadequate resources perpetuates cycles of suffering and worsens existing emergencies[13]. There is a reliance solely on humanitarian efforts, which falls short in the long term[12]. used_contexts.21: Regrettably, a quick resolution to this funding crisis remains elusive.Each year, the United Nations appeals to its member states for funds to respond to global crises and provide lifesaving assistance, including food, sanitation, healthcare, and shelter. used_contexts.31: Countries must work with greater determination to prevent conflicts and reduce vulnerability.
